data.value: Solves problems of the following form:

\min_x \ & c^T x \\
\mbox{such that} \ & b_l \leq A x \leq b_u,\\
& l \leq x \leq u, \\
& x_i \in \mathbb{Z}, i \in X_i
is a vector of decision variables;
is the set of indices of decision variables that must be integral. (In this context, a variable that can assume only integer values is said to be "integral"; it has an "integrality" constraint.)

b_l <= A @ x <= b_u
l <= x <= u
Specified elements of x must be integers

is a wrapper of the HiGHS linear optimization software . The algorithm is deterministic, and it typically finds the global optimum of moderately challenging mixed-integer linear programs (when it exists).
The coefficients of the linear objective function to be minimized.
is converted to a double precision array before the problem is solved.
Indicates the type of integrality constraint on each decision variable.
Bounds on the decision variables. Lower and upper bounds are converted to double precision arrays before the problem is solved. The
object is ignored. If not specified, all decision variables are constrained to be non-negative.
Linear constraints of the optimization problem. Arguments may be one of the following:
A single tuple that can be converted to a
A sequence composed entirely of objects of type 1. and 2.
Before the problem is solved, all values are converted to double precision, and the matrices of constraint coefficients are converted to instances of
A dictionary of solver options. The following keys are recognized.
. The object is guaranteed to have the following attributes.
Consider the problem at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integer_programming#Example, which is expressed as a maximization problem of two variables. Since
requires that the problem be expressed as a minimization problem, the objective function coefficients on the decision variables are:
Note the negative sign: we maximize the original objective function by minimizing the negative of the objective function.
We collect the coefficients of the constraints into arrays like:
Because there is no lower limit on these constraints, we have defined a variable
full of values representing negative infinity. This may be unfamiliar to users of
, which only accepts "less than" (or "upper bound") inequality constraints of the form
makes it easy to specify "greater than" inequality constraints, "less than" inequality constraints, and equality constraints concisely.
These arrays are collected into a single
The non-negativity bounds on the decision variables are enforced by default, so we do not need to provide an argument for
Finally, the problem states that both decision variables must be integers:
Note that had we solved the relaxed problem (without integrality constraints):

link.data: # from scipy.optimize import linprog; res = linprog(c, A, b_u)

data.value: we would not have obtained the correct solution by rounding to the nearest integers.
